Speaker.P: I am somewhat late in raising a point, but I think I have an opportunity to do so on this Schedule. I have a feeling in my mind in regard to the procedure in this Bill concerning income tax assessments based on the previous year's income. I came to the conclusion this morning that there is real risk of injustice being done under the Bill as it stands, and I want to ask the Minister a question. It seems to me that the matter affects a large number of people, but I shall take particularly civil servants as a class. The point about which I want to be satisfied is this. There are a large number of people who pay and have paid their income tax regularly on the actual amount received in a year. They are salaried people receiving fixed salaries, and many of them will continue to receive those salaries until their time comes for pension. It does not matter whether that time comes next year or ten years hence. They will have paid their tax on the money received until their pensions come, and then will apparently pay on money they received in the previous year. That means that they will have paid twice over when they are in receipt of a smaller income. If that is correct I think it will do serious injustice to a large class of salaried people who expect to be put on pension at a certain time, as they will be penalised if the Bill goes through as it stands. I may be wrong in my view, but I want to be satisfied on the point.
The position is all right. The position is that when employment would have ceased the amount of tax would be reduced in the first year of pension.
That applies to civil servants?
Yes.

I do not think that that answer goes quite far enough as I have other cases in mind. I will take the opportunity of speaking about them to the Minister before the Report Stage. I have cases in mind where salaries diminish even though employment does not cease. If they pay on money received in the previous year they will be assessed on the larger sum.

I would like to have particulars of individual or typical cases from the Deputy so that I could have them looked into. On the other hand, if a person got an increase of salary and paid on the amount received in the previous year he would gain an advantage. I will look at any cases which the Deputy may put up.

The advantage in the case referred to would really only be suspension of payment because payment would be held over until the following year. If there was a disadvantage it would be a permanent loss to the individual. The Minister appears to be satisfied in regard to pension cases.

FIFTH SCHEDULE.
I move:—
To insert at the end of the Fifth Schedule a new paragraph as follows:—

“All mechanically propelled vehicles whose motive power is electricity derived from a storage battery affixed to the vehicles, whether for use as hackney carriages or for the conveyance of merchandise—£1 per vehicle.”

MainHeading.P: The purpose of this amendment is, by reducing the tax on electrical vehicles to a nominal figure, to popularise them. The amendment is not prompted by Mr. Drumm's invention concerning which the Minister for Industry and Commerce gave us such an encouraging account. It is, of course, altogether too soon to legislate for such a revolution as that and I would not be guilty of such immodesty. This matter was mentioned last year in the discussion on the Budget and the Minister for Finance then expressed sympathy with the idea of introducing such vehicles in substitution for the present type of motor vehicles. Since then the use of electrical vehicles in most countries has increased. In Berlin electrically-driven taxis have been introduced and are competing with the ordinary type of motor vehicle and plying at a cheaper rate. In England the Post Office recently placed an order for a big number of delivery vans for use in London and Leeds. In America their use is rapidly extending and in Italy Signor Mussolini has ordered that no taxation of any kind shall be chargeable on those vehicles although Italy has a very big manufacturing industry in ordinary motor vehicles. In the Saorstát there has been comparatively no interest taken in such vehicles up to the present. I do not think that there are more than three or four registered throughout the country.

In Belfast, however, a bakery company has about half a dozen delivery vans of that type in constant use and has found them admirable for the purposes of town delivery work. Primarily, the case for the vehicle is that it is vastly more satisfactory to have our transport based on native power than on fuel which has to be transported thousands of miles. No one has to be told that petrol is very much in the hands of trusts and that the price is liable to be changed from time to time by arbitrary methods. The Executive Council have confessed that they can do nothing to control the price of petrol. Even the British Government has been unable to do anything in that way to meet the outery of the motoring community which was raised some time ago when the increase in the price of motor spirit was announced. In addition to that factor, the cost of motor spirit which is now approaching £1,000,000 per year is a very big tax on the country.

If this amendment is passed I do not expect for a moment that there will be an immediate demand for electrically-driven vehicles. There are no special battery-charging facilities in the country and I understand that a manufacturer of electrical vehicles who visited the Saorstát last year with a view to ascertaining whether facilities would be provided by the municipal authorities here did not get much encouragement in that direction. As well as that, the fact that the battery has to be charged for every fifty or sixty miles' journey would be a deterrent. But in view of the great importance and the great economy of these vehicles from the national point of view and in view of the importance of having transport, as far as possible, independent of outside troubles and outside influences, it seems a most desirable thing that some encouragement should be given to the users of vehicles of this kind. I think all will agree that at the moment, when electrical power is almost ready for distribution throughout the Saorstát, some action should be taken with a view to bringing such vehicles to the notice of the commercial public and giving an impetus to their use. The vehicles have been described as having the advantage of being easily controlled by unskilled labour; they have a high figure of reliability due to simple construction and the absence of rotating parts. Consequently they have low repair costs. They are clean, sanitary and free from fire risk. If this amendment is passed the Road Fund will not lose any appreciable amount, and even if it did, the loss would be well repaid by the national advantages that would accrue. I submit to the Dáil that by passing the amendment and offering a remission of taxation for a period on electrically-propelled vehicles they would be doing something that is bound to do good to the transport system of the country and that cannot possibly have any injurious reactions.

Speaker.P: This proposal, as the Deputy has suggested, would affect a very small number of vehicles. In fact, I believe it would affect five. Three of them are not really commercial vehicles and are taxed at the £6 rate. There are just two electrically-driven vehicles taxed at the commercial rate of £30 or something like that. It seems to me that it is really premature to fix any special rate, as suggested by the Deputy, for electrically-driven vehicles. I believe if we had come to the point where there was soon a likelihood of some considerable increase in the number of electrically-driven vehicles we would not and could not fix it as low as this. If these vehicles were likely to come on the road in any numbers, I think it would be necessary, in view of the fact that the Road Fund is definitely for the purpose of getting money for road maintenance, to charge them some reasonable rate. On the other hand, if there was an increase in the number of electrically-driven vehicles, it would be held up as a great injustice to individuals who bought their vehicles when the tax was only £1, if they were asked to pay £30 or £40 or whatever sum they might have to pay for a heavy vehicle. I think the Deputy's amendment is premature, and apart from that, I think that it really goes too far.

MainHeading.P: We have hopes that there will be a great increase, as a result of the invention which has been mentioned here, in the use of electrically-driven vehicles. If that comes about we will undoubtedly have to consider the position of electrically-propelled vehicles; but I do not think, in the event of our hope being realised, that we could possibly agree to a rate of £1 per vehicle, because if there was a substantial increase in the number of electrically-driven vehicles the position would be that there would be so many more on the road, and if there was an income of only £1 from each of them the Road Fund would be depleted and we would be driven back to the position of having the taxpayer, or in the case of rural roads, the farmer who does not gain so much out of the good roads, taxed to maintain them at a standard suitable for this sort of vehicle. For the present, there is no money involved, but I would suggest that the Deputy should not press the amendment. When the position is clarified he could bring forward his proposals again. If he were doing that, I do not think that we could go to the length which his amendment suggests. We know that one of the difficulties in connection with any increase in tax is that people complain that their calculations are put out and that they are charged a much higher rate on a vehicle than they had to pay when they bought it.

Speaker.P: I think the Minister has certainly made a very bad case against Deputy Moore's amendment. After all, it is up to the Government to give a lead in matters such as this. We have spent, or are spending, at least £5,000,000 in trying to produce electricity in this country. Surely to goodness, even if the Government had to pay into the Road Fund from other funds, the sum which they would lose by taking the tax off electrically-driven vehicles, they should do so. Even under the old conditions it has been proved that in a great many parts of the world the electrically-driven van or truck is suitable for delivery in towns. In another year or so we will have hundreds of thousands of units of electrical power simply going to waste. Before we find ourselves in that condition surely some provision or some arrangement should be made to consume practically all the electricity we are going to produce.

MainHeading.P: The Shannon scheme is going to be a load on the taxpayers in this country until the total production is used, and this suggestion of Deputy Moore would certainly increase the number of electrically-driven vehicles. It is always difficult to get people to use new machinery of any description. It is going to take them some years, and the sooner we start the better. There is absolutely no point in the argument of the Minister that if we take off the tax now it would be very hard to put it on again. It can be clearly stated that the relief in taxation on electrically-propelled vehicles is simply for the purpose of encouraging electric power, and no promise will be held out that that relief is going to be permanent. But even temporary relief will undoubtedly have the result of increasing the popularity of such vehicles, and we should aim at that at the moment.

Speaker.P: I do not know that I have very much to add to what Deputy Moore and Deputy Aiken have said except that it appears to me that the Minister did not quite get the purpose of Deputy Moore's amendment. It had no relation at all, except in an indirect way, to the number of electrically-propelled vehicles in general use beyond the fact that Deputy Moore is anxious to increase the number. The fact that there are at present not more than six, of which three might be described as commercial vehicles, shows that there should be some inducement offered to those using vehicles for the purpose of their business to adopt more generally electrically-propelled machinery. It had not any reference either, except an indirect reference, to the invention to which the Minister referred and which invention is still in its development stage. It has possibilities, and very big possibilities, for the future of this country probably, but on the other hand the Shannon scheme is a certainty. There is going to be, I believe, at the earlier stages at any rate, some difficulty in disposing of the full output of the scheme, and one of the ways in which the output can be used, or portion of it, would be by utilising it in driving commercial vehicles in the country.

Speaker.P: How many million units would be used?
I am not aware how many million units would be available or taken.
How many thousand units would be used?

A very considerable number. I have not the statistics, but I know that in Great Britain and other countries electrically-propelled vehicles are in very general use and that they are increasing. I have seen them used very generally in Germany and also in Great Britain, but we know that they are hardly used at all in this country. We know if they were in more general use the problem of the Electricity Supply Board would be an easier one. As well as that there is the other point of view. We are importing petrol to the value approximately of something like a million pounds a year. The whole of that supply is controlled at the present moment by three or four large concerns operating under an agreement and in unison with each other. The price of petrol is very much higher here than in Great Britain. There may be sound commercial reasons why that should be so, but I suggest that if we have an alternative source of motive power we should encourage it, even if only from the point of view of bringing ourselves from under the petrol rings and combines.

MainHeading.P: For that reason I think the Minister should consider sympathetically this amendment. As has been said, it is not going to result in any loss to the Exchequer. The electric vehicle has a certain advantage, but commercial people in these matters are sometimes liable to err on the side of conservatism. It has its disadvantages also, but there are certain fields in which it has a decided advantage over the petrol-propelled vehicle or the steam-propelled vehicle. I think the Minister should seriously consider whether in the present circumstances he would not offer some inducement to people to overcome their timidity, to overcome their lack of familiarity with the invention. If he is disposed to consider the principle that Deputy Moore has embodied in his amendment we could then go into details as to whether the amendment errs on the side of offering too great an inducement. Perhaps the Minister will say that one pound per vehicle is unduly low. Let us admit that for the purpose of argument. At the same time it does not altogether counter the proposal that there should be preferential treatment given to vehicles that use native motive power, and which depend for their power of propulsion on native energy over vehicles run on fuel which is imported. That is the principle that Deputy Moore is anxious to impress upon this House. I think the Minister might consider, in these circumstances, whether he could not go some way to meet Deputy Moore, and whether in the present circumstances, taking time by the forelock, in order that a substantial number of these vehicles may be introduced by the time the Shannon current is available, he should not in the present Finance Bill act upon the principle which the Deputy has proposed to the House.

Speaker.P: I would like to ask the Minister to say whether he is in agreement with the views which the amendment of Deputy Moore puts before the House. Is he prepared to say that he is anxious to promote, or to help to promote, the use of electrical current in vehicles throughout the Free State, and if he is going to say that if this amount of one pound is rather low he might be prepared to consider a different figure, but a figure still lower than the rate charged on ordinary vehicles? The Minister for Industry and Commerce interjected a remark and asked Deputy MacEntee how many million units would be used for the charging of the batteries. That is beside the question altogether. The point is that we are going to have either an over-production or an under-production of electric current. If the invention that we have heard so much about proves to be a success. I have no hesitation in saying that we will have an under-production of current from the Shannon scheme.
Why do you say that?
Because of the remarks made by the Minister in regard to the new invention.
Not in regard to cars.

No, in regard to the railway. I say that if the invention is a success there will be an under-production of electricity on the Shannon scheme. On the other hand, if this invention does not materialise we will be faced with an over-production, and, therefore, we will have to have another outlet through these cars.
Through these cars?

In various ways nobody can say whether those generally used would prove to be satisfactory or not. Deputy Moore has asked that the State should make it possible for the thing to be tried out without any cost to the State. After all every electrical car would save to the State the amount of money paid for its petrol. Putting it at a small figure I should say that every petrol propelled car in the State must lose to the State £25 per year for petrol used and that would be on the calculation of ten gallons per week. If you save to the State £25 of the capital exported for petrol for each car and if you multiply that, even by the small figure of one hundred, you will be able to examine the possibilities. By adopting this amendment you will be giving the same facility to those who want to put it to the test. On the other hand on the present basis if you do not give some lead to people who want to try these things you are going to stunt from the beginning the experiments they would make. At the same time if the preference is given them, in three or four years time you would have some experience and knowledge and we would see whether or not they were going to be used. The Minister could say, “I will not accept the suggestion of one pound, I will make it two pounds.” or some other figure and not turn it down altogether. We want to try and stop the importation of fuel from outside and to use native power instead. This is one way it might be done. I hope if the Minister does not accept the amendment he will give us some indication to show that he is anxious to develop the use of electrically driven vehicles. Even if the Minister for Industry and Commerce thinks it is not going to use many thousands of units every vehicle driven by electrical power will save to the State the cost of the petrol used for that vehicle.

I interjected a remark because, in coming into the House, I heard somebody pleading that this would be suitable and useful to the Shannon scheme. No figures were given, and all sorts of absurd statements were made as to over-production and under-production of electricity. I hope to give people an opportunity quite soon to discuss the final cost of the Shannon scheme and then we might get that point about over-production and under-production argued. I interjected the remark I made because of what I heard, and Deputy Briscoe was inclined to decry my interjection, and said himself that this is a way in which the State might help the Shannon scheme. I say this particular proposal, taken by itself, will not help the Shannon scheme. What is going to make people run vehicles on electricity or what has prevented them running vehicles on electricity on the roads at the present moment? Two or three things— the price of the battery that has to be used, its fragility, its maintenance, cost, and the difficulty in charging it.
And the tax on cars.

The tax on cars is a relatively unimportant thing. Remember if there is a decent battery which is better in many ways than the present batteries, which are unsuitable, either as to weight or bulk or charging time, the cost of lighting, of fuel price of the Shannon current in comparison with the price of petrol, then the reduction of the tax on the vehicle is not going to matter. If there is ever a battery invented that will allow of electrical traction on the roads immediately, then, if I were Minister for Finance, I would look to those vehicles as a considerable source of new revenue, because they would be getting fuel so cheaply by way of the Shannon current that they would be quite properly an object for further taxation.

MainHeading.P: I have not heard any argument used with regard to this amendment other than this relating to the Shannon scheme. I do not think it matters anything, at the present moment, to the Shannon scheme with batteries as they are at present. The reduction of this tax would not help to consume an extra 5,000 units in a year. I think people should wait until they find out what the prospects are of Shannon current being taken in other ways before going to this absurd extent of trying in a very futile way to encourage the use of electricity.

Supposing there is a development which takes place with regard to the use of electricity on road vehicles. It is hardly an opportune time now to assist a possible development by reducing the tax, because if that development came about there would probably be not a reduction of the tax so far as the car itself is concerned, but an increase, and even when there was an increase the consumer of electricity for use on the road would be in a far better position than the owner of the petrol-driven car to-day. If it seemed to me that there was going to be any immediate encouragement of, or any growth of traction on the roads under electrical power simply by reason of this, I would back it, but it is the worst possible way to approach the whole thing. There will be no increase, and when things are in a transitional stage it is rather a bad time to commit ourselves to an amendment of this kind. There may be other arguments I have not heard, but so far as the electricity is concerned, and so far as the development of the Shannon scheme is concerned——

Speaker.P: There is the adverse trade balance.
How are you going to affect the trade balance, unless there is some great change made?

The Minister for Industry and Commerce is more surprising than the Minister for Finance. He asks what is the use. There is no doubt about it that in the principal big cities in different parts of the world electrically-propelled vehicles possess enough advantage for different commercial concerns that have scrapped their petrol vehicles and procured electrically-propelled vehicles even with the old batteries. We are told by Deputy Moore that there are only about five electrically-propelled vehicles in this country at the present time. We have nothing to say for the owners of these vehicles. I do not know one of them myself. It may cost the Minister for Finance £50 to take the tax off these vehicles. Of course, the Minister for Industry and Commerce would say what is the use. He says the increased consumption of electricity would be about 5,000 units. He gave no facts on which he bases that calculation. I would like to ask him will any single advertisement put in by the Electricity Supply Board into the ordinary papers produce an additional consumption of 5,000 units. I think the Electricity Supply Board would have to spend more than £50 to get an additional consumption from their advertisements. Even looking upon this purely and solely as an advertisement for electricity, it would do a lot of good and might result in a lot of people in commercial concerns at the present time using petrol vehicles, sitting up and taking notice and going to some trouble to find out whether it would not be better for them to turn over to electrically - propelled vehicles. Even if the consumption of electricity, lighting, heating and power in factories was more than the total production of the Shannon scheme, there are other rivers in the country. As long as we can get power of our own we should endeavour in every possible way to use that power instead of continuing to use imported power from abroad. We have plenty of rivers here as well as the Shannon, and if the Shannon production was being used up there are other sources of supplies that could be called upon. I hope the Minister for Finance will accept Deputy Moore's amendment. It is not going to mean anything very much to the Exchequer this year. But it is going to mean a lot to the country as a whole. It is a step in the right direction, the using of our own native power which we produce here instead of importing petrol or motor spirit from abroad.

I think the House will welcome the announcement from the Minister for Industry and Commerce with regard to the 1929 Shannon Bill. I think that anyone who has read the two Bills will recognise that there are gaps, technical and financial gaps, which will require to be filled.
They are not going to be filled in this Bill.

Then it will have to be by the 1930 Bill. At any rate there are sections in it at the present moment which are utterly inoperative and could not be operated even by the Minister for Industry and Commerce. At any rate, we will be glad when he does give that opportunity, and I am quite sure the newly-constituted House, the House which now comes to deal with the Shannon scheme, will deal with it in the spirit of co-operation so as to see what is the best that can be got out of that scheme for the country. The Minister made the remark that the battery which he was envisaging at the moment was for rail and not for road.
I did not say that.
I understood him to say that that was the development which was more likely to be taken.
In the official announcement it was.

I do not know—somebody said the official announcement —frankly, I do not know which is the official announcement. The official announcement which was made in this House in relation to it was made in a debate, frankly and freely, by the Minister for Industry and Commerce. That announcement was deliberately suppressed out of the reports by the Press the next day. That was an announcement that was unanimously missing out of the reports in all the Press on the following day.
The Deputy had better deal with the amendment.
I think possibly the Minister for Industry and Commerce might like to explain to the House why that occurred.

The Minister for Industry and Commerce could not explain that to the House on this amendment. The Minister has nothing to do with that. The Deputy must deal with this amendment, and not with what appears or does not appear in the Press.

Very well, I will deal with the amendment. The suggestion here is that the Minister for Finance should throw his bread upon the waters; in other words, that he should encourage in advance the use of electrically-propelled vehicles in order that their possibilities and advantages should be known to the community. Frankly, I think that anyone who does put an electrically-propelled vehicle on the road at the present moment will be doing a very real service in the sense that he will be making known to the general body of the community the possibilities of that development. I do not think that the man who will be doing that at the present rate of tax, at the present cost of power, and with the present cost of batteries, will be doing himself a service. There are in this country certain roads, there are the by-roads of Ireland, on which it would not be safe to run an electrically-propelled vehicle. I am sure that, as at present constructed, they would suffer grievously, because electrical batteries, as we have them at present, are heavy, with no structural strength. These are subject to very high strain and have no mechanical strength to stand the strain. I do not think, as far as I know, that they could be designed at the present moment—we could not design an economic battery for that purpose which would in volume, in bulk and weight be suitable for all roads. Therefore I say that to the extent to which any person will put an electrically-driven vehicle on the road and run this on the average road, he will be giving very valuable technical information to the community and doing very valuable pioneer work.

MainHeading.P: We will get to know from the use of these vehicles on the road some very valuable information. We will get to know their effect on road maintenance. You have not got anything that those rough starting shocks like you get on the ordinary motor car ordinarily driven. A good many of the ordinary mechanical features of the motor car which are destructive to the roads do not exist in the electrically-propelled motor vehicles. I think it would pay the Minister for Industry and Commerce; it would pay the Minister for Finance, and most certainly it would pay the Minister for Local Government and Public Health to deliberately run such vehicles on the road for the purpose of the information they would get. It has been suggested that these electrically-driven vehicles at the moment are impracticable, both because of cost and everything else. They are not. Many years ago some hundreds of taxi cabs were put on the roads in London. These taxi cabs were driven electrically in the city of London, and they broke down only through a technical difficulty. The batteries that were sent out with these vehicles were batteries which were guaranteed by the firm which sent them out, on the condition that they were never to discharge below a certain voltage, that is 1.8. What in actual practice happened was that the people used to run them until they came to that voltage, and then they used to try to run them home to the garage, but the fall in voltage after 1.8 is vertical. The result was that one after another the whole of these batteries were rejected and left in the hands of the owners on this technical guarantee. Whether the Minister in the new batteries will be able to give that latitude which is necessary is the question. I mean that the rough misuse, the grossly rough misuse which in practice a battery in a motor car will undoubtedly get in the hands of the ordinary user is the matter on which this latitude is necessary. Every one of us has experience of running a car home on a flat tyre, and all of us have had experience of running a car the last couple of miles after we have discovered that there is not enough oil in the pump, and in that way getting home somehow under certain difficulties.

Speaking with considerable knowledge of the idiosyncrasies of batteries as at present designed I want to say that a battery is one of the things which you must not misuse in that way. If the Minister for Finance, the Minister for Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Local Government and Public Health were to put a certain series of vehicles upon the road in Ireland where they might be run out of current in a place where they would be two or three miles away from the station where the battery could be charged the position could be envisaged for the future. In the running of these cars we would have the position that mis-use would be normal as distinct from the condition in the city, where you would have a regular garage, and a time for running. In that way very valuable information would be obtained.

What the Minister would lose in that would be negligible compared with what would be gained. The Minister for Industry and Commerce said that the cost of current from the Shannon scheme when put into the batteries would be so low that it would practically wipe out the existing cost of the licence duty. If the Minister for Industry and Commerce is prepared to provide Shannon current for nothing even with an efficient battery and certainly with the battery as we have it now, the mere cost of putting that current commercially into the battery would, in my opinion at the present moment, mean that the cost of driving that electrically propelled vehicle would be probably higher than the cost of petrol, without any initial cost whatever in the way of current. There is in addition the difficulty of having your car held up while getting charged or the difficulty of transferring a complete set of batteries in substitution for another set. There is the maintenance of the electrically charged stations all over the country all of which would have to be charged up to the cost, so that the more raw material of electricity which is supplied by the Shannon scheme will be a very small part of the total cost of the current when it is actually in operation. For that reason, I hope that the Minister for Industry and Commerce has not been rosily optimistic and I hope he will deliver the goods. Certainly in no part of the House will the Minister and those responsible for the Shannon scheme get heartier and more sincere congratulations than he will on this side of the House.

Speaker.P: Did I ever say anything in regard to these batteries with regard to the price?

That is the difficulty. I rather put the point to the Minister at the beginning that he had not recommended the battery for road vehicles, and from that I was going to infer that the difficulty we have in envisaging a battery for road vehicles has not been solved as far as this new invention is concerned.
Surely all this is outside the particular matter that we are considering.

I am endeavouring to answer the Minister's speech. If I am out of order, then the whole speech of the Minister must have been out of order. I am simply dealing with what he said or inferred. I gathered from the Minister that this battery, as far as he envisaged it— and I am not pressing for any unnecessary information — was a battery which was going to be more suitable for railways than for road vehicles. At any rate, he did not envisage it in relation to road vehicles; he envisaged it as a battery which could be used under the conditions in which a battery could be used on rails. In the case of rails you are using your battery with a whole terminal system behind it. You are using it on a perfectly smooth roadway, and you are using it at regular hours and under conditions where you will require a very considerable weight to give you rail adhesion in your driving engine. Those are the conditions as far as rails are concerned.

The Deputy is now arguing about a particular type of battery, whether it can be used on roads or rails or on both. There is nothing in this amendment about that. The amendment is supposed to apply to electrically-propelled vehicles irrespective of the particular type of battery, or what way they may be driven so long as they are driven by electricity. Therefore, that portion of the Deputy's speech dealing with a particular type of battery is not relevant to this amendment. The Minister for Industry and Commerce made a passing reference, and the Deputy is trying to develop that and make a speech out of it.
I am not. You have put in the strongest possible way the argument which I was going to submit.
If that is so, then there is no necessity for the Deputy further to comment upon it.
You have argued——
I have not argued. I have pointed out that the Deputy's speech is irrelevant.
The Leas-Cheann Comhairle has pointed out that this amendment refers to all mechanically-propelled vehicles.
I have not said any such thing. I mentioned electrically-propelled vehicles.
All mechanical electrically-propelled vehicles. In other words, it applies to human beings, and it only applies to them if we take them on the literal interpretation.
The Deputy is trying to galvanise it.
The sea-green incorruptible cannot be galvanised.
I advise the Deputy to confine himself strictly to the amendment.

It is desirable that we should get information in relation to the use of electrically-propelled vehicles under actual conditions on Irish roads. It is desirable that the Minister should make some concessions now to those to whom it will be, under present conditions, unprofitable to run vehicles for the purpose of getting that information.

To the person not mechanically-minded, most of Deputy Flinn's speech and his arguments might appear somewhat obscure. At the same time there is much in his speech and his argument that the Minister for Industry and Commerce might take serious notice of. I was left wondering as to whether the Deputy was supporting or opposing the amendment. I had some doubt also on reading this amendment as to whether the figure of £1 mentioned in it had any relation to other figures for vehicles propelled in another way. We have suggested in the amendment £1 per vehicle for all mechanically-propelled vehicles whose motive power is electrical derived through a storage battery, whereas in the Fifth Schedule, to which this is an amendment, we have varying rates on certain mechanically-propelled vehicles going from £70 to £160, and £5 for every additional person. I wonder if Deputy Moore has considered his figure of £1 in relation to the other figures mentioned in the Fifth Schedule.

MainHeading.P: My chief reason for rising was to clear up some confusion that must have existed in Deputy Flinn's mind when making a reference for which he was called to order. I have over thirty years' experience of the newspaper profession in all its branches. Whether it is due to the acoustic properties of this House or not, or to the inaudibility of certain members when they are speaking, I am not prepared to say at the moment, but it does occur to me that very serious injustice is done to a very hard-working lot of men when it is declared that they have deliberately omitted certain things from their reports. I know what it is. I have gone through the mill myself. To suggest that they would deliberately or with malice aforethought leave out what to them would be a very valuable fact and a decided asset to their business, is very unreasonable. Last week the Minister for Industry and Commerce was in bad voice and he was not even audible on these benches.

Speaker.P: Might I interrupt——
It was most difficult for any Pressman to report the Minister on that occasion.
I prevented Deputy Flinn from dealing with that matter, and I will not allow Deputy Anthony to deal with it now. It is quite irrelevant to what is under discussion.

Reference to the matter now might mean that if Ministers have important announcements to make they should hand a copy of what they will say to the Press or endeavour to speak more audibly. As I have said, there is much in Deputy Flinn's argument that the Minister should take notice of. I know he is very well able to deal with the matter suggested in this amendment, knowing as I do that he has had a long experience of electrical engineering. Whilst giving Deputy Flinn all credit for his enthusiasm in this particular direction, it would appear to me that the main purpose of his speech was to draw from the Minister some further information regarding the invention of which we are all proud. We are proud that an Irishman is the inventor and that an Irish Government will be able to help that inventor to perfect his invention.

MainHeading.P: I do not think at any rate that the Minister for Industry and Commerce is so easily drawn, and I think that Deputy Flinn in labouring that portion of his address has missed the point which I personally was most interested in. The getting of further information would be useful and we would all appreciate it, but I fear that Deputy Flinn has defeated the object which he sought to achieve. In any case I had hoped that the Minister would give us a little further enlightenment in this matter. We were encouraged here last week and if when replying he would answer some of the points raised by Deputy Flinn it would also be of great interest to many of us outside Dublin. The point raised by Deputy Flinn, so far as electrically propelled vehicles run on rails or on the roads are concerned, is one which I think could be very easily answered by the Minister.

Speaker.P: The Chair will not let you. I was stopped.

I would like the Minister to answer it. Of course there is a very big difference. These mechanically propelled vehicles on the road are quite a different problem altogether from vehicles which are propelled along a railway. The points raised by Deputy Flinn are of interest and I suggest the Minister should consider in his reply the desirability and advisability of having some of those points cleared up. They would be of very great interest to very many mechanically minded people in this country and in view of recent developments and particularly in view of what to my mind is a wonderful achievement of a young Irishman it would be interesting to the community and the Minister would be well advised to enlighten us further on the subject.

When I was talking the Minister asked me if I had any statistics, but I have not. Like some members of the Executive Council, I do not rely for my statistics on my memory when I am on my feet. The Minister suggested that an electrically-propelled vehicle was definitely inferior to the petrol-driven vehicle in commercial use. I do not think that is so. There have been a considerable number of electrical vehicles in use in Great Britain for a number of years, and very careful records kept as to the all-in cost, including wages, depreciation and repairs. I think it has been found where they have to operate within a short radius, say up to 30 or 35 miles, and operate over normal roads— not necessarily above the average class of roads, but where good and bad roads obtain, as they do in most countries—electrically-propelled vehicles work out slightly cheaper than petrol-driven vehicles where the cost of current for charging purposes does not exceed, I think, one half-penny per unit.

As to the effect which the general introduction of these vehicles in this country might have on the Shannon scheme, of course the Minister is in a much better position to deal with the matter than I am. He has all the figures before him, but I proceed on the basis that the average consumption of electricity by an electrically-propelled vehicle is 40 units per day. If we assume one of those vehicles will operate for 300 days in the year, your average consumption then will be 12,000 units per year. I understand there are 45,000 mechanically-propelled vehicles running on the roads of the Free State. If we assume 2 per cent., or 1,000 of these vehicles were to be replaced by battery-driven vehicles, we would have 1,000 battery-driven vehicles on the road, each using 12,000 units per annum, which I think in all would give a total consumption for propulsion of 12,000,000 units. I understand the Minister proposes in the intial stages of the Shannon scheme to sell as his maximum something like 120 million units per annum.
110 to consumers.

I said 120. We will take it at 100. Ten million units is ten per cent. I understand it is not going to be an easy job by any means to sell the 110 million units here. It is going to take four or five years at least to reach that consumption.
Where did you get that?
According to the expert's report.
No.
The Minister is in a good humour.
Four or five years from the date on which they wrote the report.
What is the consumption of electricity in the Free State at present? Can the Minister give us any figures for that?
We are not discussing the Shannon scheme.

I am not going to suggest that it is going to be an easy proposition. I am not going to say it cannot be done. I believe it can. I believe the market for electricity is just as wide as the Minister believes, and as the experts in electricity have said it is, but it is a market which at present is undeveloped. It will take them some time to sell that. Here there is a way in which we suggest he can sell——
Twelve million units.

Yes, I think that is a very appreciable consumption. It is well worth going after, and not only that, but it is twelve million units which is going to be generated during the night. As far as we know, he has not found a use for it. One of the advantages of the battery-propelled vehicles is that they can be charged during the night. That is one of the reasons why in Great Britain they are able to offer current for battery charging purposes at a farthing per unit in some cases. As well as that it is also convenient to charge them during the dinner hour, when you have a valley on the lode curve of the station, and consequently, from the point of view of equalising the lode on the Shannon scheme, they would be useful.
Deputy Flinn stated that when batteries were required to be charged the electricity could not be got at the moment.
I said under our conditions.
I am not subscribing to that proposition at all. I believe even in the present circumstances——
You could get 12,000,000 units.
Provided you offer an inducement now to the electrically-propelled vehicles.
By reducing the price considerably.

By giving preferential treatment to these people. I admit the balance of advantage on the side of electrically-propelled vehicles is very slight. In Great Britain, where they have worked that out, they have found that for machines which have to operate within a limited radius, the balance of advantage, taking into consideration the depreciation of the battery and everything else, is on the side of electrically-propelled vehicles, but it is not so great at present as to induce people to say “We are going to risk our money in the electrically-propelled machines,” as the first cost is higher. They should know that there is not going to be trouble over the battery if it is going to be handled properly. That side of the question, the development of the new battery as distinct from the old sulphuric acid battery, has been proceeding rapidly, and those can be handled with comparative security by an unskilled man. You can take greater liberties with them. They are cheaper to purchase, and possibly have greater advantages, but to everything the Minister has stated and used as arguments against Deputy Moore's amendment a contra technical argument can be put up. This is not the place to discuss it, but for certain limited uses there are occasions where the vehicle may be used for distribution purposes within a certain limited area. The slight balance of advantage is on the slide of electrically-propelled vehicles. As against that, you have the fact that the electrically-propelled vehicle costs more owing to the fact that its early development was not so fortunate as the petrol-driven machine.

MainHeading.P: You have a bad reputation attaching to these batteries—dangers of handling and so on—and,therefore, people must be given an inducement to overcome their timidity in respect to them. We are asking that it should be done. We believe that if you do give an inducement it is going to be beneficial to the Shannon scheme. When I say that I do not at all—bleat as the Minister described it—say that the Shannon scheme is not going to be a success, but I do feel that we have got to put forward our best efforts to make it a success. This is one way in which you can sell some of the current you are generating in the Shannon scheme. The encouragement which you give the electrically-propelled road vehicle is not I understand from the Minister at all going to react unfavourably on the development of another invention which the Minister for Industry and Commerce has in mind. Apart altogether from whether it is going to be of assistance——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. Sheehy (Cork) Mr. T. Sheehy (Cork)
Speaker.P: (Cork): Between the two, I think your own battery will be soon exhausted.

I agree. I am depending for my propulsion upon the electrical energy which operates here (indicating his head). The Deputy when he legislates depends upon the mechanical energy which operates in his pedal extremities. He does not legislate with his head; he is one of those who legislate with their feet. Consequently he feels that his limited supply of intellectual stimulus may be exhausted. If he were trying to argue a case of this sort— I agree that he is not competent to argue it. I was hoping that I might convince the Minister to agree to allow the Minister for Finance to act upon his better judgment, because we certainly had a feeling on these benches before the Minister for Industry and Commerce came along that the Minister for Finance was disposed rather favourably to consider the principle embodied in Deputy Moore's amendment. We think that we have made at any rate an unanswerable case for it. We think if the Minister for Industry and Commerce is sincerely desirous to do something to reduce the unfavourable trade balance he will try to do something to keep the unnecessary import of petrol into this country down, instead of sitting quietly by while over one million pounds' worth of petrol is imported into this country. We think that he ought to see that some of the energy produced in this country should replace that petrol and thereby readjust the unfavourable trade balance. It is quite possible that there may be interests at the back of the Minister and of the Minister's Government who are opposed to the restriction of the imports of petrol. It is possible that they want the petrol market still to be reserved for them, and that, therefore, they are not favourable to considering an amendment like this upon the merits and that therefore the hitherto inexplicable opposition of the Minister to an amendment of this sort may be explained.

This matter of preference for electrically-propelled motor vehicles was considered by the Inter-Departmental Committee of Civil Servants which considered the bus tax. During recent months that Committee recommended that the Government should consider giving a preference to electrically-propelled vehicles; to charge them at half the rate that was charged for vehicles driven by petrol. The Government neither accepted nor rejected that recommendation. We postponed consideration of it. I do not want to go into any details about the battery in which the Minister for Industry and Commerce is interested, but we felt that we were probably on the eve of considerable new development in connection with the use of electricity in transport. The civil servants who made the recommendation had no information that the invention, the development of which was being assisted, had relation to an electrical battery. We have to wait to see what the position is going to be. It may be that there will be no need to give any other assistance to electrically-propelled vehicles. On the other hand, it may be that the position will still be that some assistance should be given. Our view is that this battery will enable home-produced power, as Deputy Aiken said, to be used instead of the power that is imported, subject to, of course, some limitations as to the sacrifice of the Road Fund revenue that will be made. I believe if there had been no prospect of changes in motor development we would probably have accepted the recommendation of the Committee, which suggested something like a half rate. I am sure that we would not be inclined to go further than that. I do think that Deputy Moore's proposal would cost more than we ought to sacrifice from the Road Fund. I said in the beginning that I thought Deputy Moore was premature, because the encouragement he wants may or may not prove to be necessary. In any case I think his proposal goes too far. A vehicle that otherwise would pay £30 ought to pay more than £1 even if it were electrically-driven.
Will the Minister put forward his own proposal of a half rate?

That was the recommendation made to the Government, but in view of certain information which the Government had at that time and which the civil servants who made the recommendation had not, we decided that we would not take this particular recommendation into consideration at the present time, but that we would postpone it.

There would be very few vehicles come under this, and the Minister would get information through the actual practice on the road. I think that the information he would get would be worth more than what he would pay for it.

Is the position then that while the Minister for Finance says even if the whole position was not in doubt by reason of a certain invention, he would not go this far? The Minister for Industry and Commerce says even if you go this far it is not going to have any effect whatever in popularising this vehicle. He as much as contemns them.
Contemns what?
Contemns electrical vehicles.
Not at all. I pointed out certain disadvantages.
resumed the Chair.

There are higher authorities than the Minister for Industry and Commerce who think that, compared with petrol-driven vehicles, they have very great advantages, and that they are to be preferred for short distance transport. The Minister for Finance says that I am premature and am going too far. I wonder what he means when he says that I am premature. Is it desirable or not that our transport should be based on native power? He has admitted that it is, yet I am premature in trying to bring about that, though the Minister for Industry and Commerce admits that even if the method I propose be accepted, it will have no immediate effect. I admit that myself, because battery-charging facilities are not available at the moment, and as well as that it will take a good while before the commercial community are familiarised with the advantages of these vehicles. But it is because it will have no immediate effect that I made the very big proposal that practically all taxation should be remitted. I think it will be admitted by every Deputy that it would be preferable to have our transport based on home power rather than on imported fuel, especially fuel that has to come such very long distances. Is it worth while offering an inducement? Is it worth while offering a sort of advertisement? Should not pioneers be encouraged for two or three years by being given special concessions? These questions have been answered with two voices, so much so that I think the Government must have thought that my proposal was a joke.

MainHeading.P: Even if we passed this amendment we would not be doing anything unique, because, as I have said, at least one great country, which has a big manufacturing industry in ordinary petrol vehicles, has decided to remit the tax on electrical vehicles, and one other country has followed on the same lines, a country which also manufactures petrol vehicles. However, I do not think that there is any desire to have a Division on the matter. The only thing we have learned is that the Government has not very much regard, apparently, to questions of this kind, so that as a proposal to improve the balance of trade, even when there is a question of about a million pounds involved, does not upset them in any way, and does not appear to meet with much consideration from them, and that such a question as having a secure basis for their transport is not a very vital matter to them. As a matter of fact, I could quote a statement which was heard by one of the highest civil servants in the State this day week to the effect that all the talk in England about coal distillation was the merest absurdity, that it could never be a commercial proposition, but that England had kept it going and has to keep it in reserve because of the possibility of an interruption in petrol supplies which would have a serious effect upon her trade. That statement was made this day week by one of the highest authorities on the subject in the presence of one of the highest civil servants in the State. In face of facts like that, are we so confident of our position that we are prepared to allow our transport to drift so that it will rapidly become dependent on that fuel, the supplies of which our neighbours in England consider are liable to interruption at any moment, and although we know that such an interruption would mean a very serious upset to the normal life of the community? I put that before the Ministers; but, as I said, in view of the present circumstances affecting the subject, we are not prepared to press the amendment to a division.

Speaker.P: I wonder if the Minister could bring in an amendment on the Report Stage which would meet what seems to be the common desire of Deputies on both sides of the House. We all admit that we want to encourage the use of native power, and when the Minister has that idea I think that he should act up to it. It seems to be that the Government has got into a rut, that they got a great inspiration and went ahead with the Shannon scheme, but that they are now falling down on the job. I think that they are very lax in not doing something to encourage the use of electrically-propelled vehicles. Deputy MacEntee has pointed out that even if two per cent. of the present petrol cars were converted into electric cars it would mean a consumption of twelve per cent. of the probable output of the Shannon. There is no doubt about it, that electrically-propelled cars are looked upon as a good economic proposition in New York. Some of the biggest concerns there use such cars, and the same obtains all over the United States. In the United States they get petrol for almost half what we have to pay for it. Their Ford cars are one-third less in price than they are here, and surely if they think that electrically-propelled cars are a good paying proposition there we should think it here, where we are under the disadvantage of having to pay almost twice as much as they do for petrol and one-third more for our cars. It should be a good-paying proposition here, even with the old battery system, and if the new battery turns out to be all that it is hoped it will be, it will simply mean changing the batteries.
No hope has yet been expressed about the battery. I said that the whole time.

I maintain that even with the present batteries electrically-propelled vehicles would not alone be made an economic proposition for individual users, but that they certainly would be a fine economic proposition from the point of view of the national position.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
Fifth and Sixth Schedules and the Title put and agreed to.

Bill reported.
